message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sickle cell disease and poorly controlled hypertension, which can lead to renal complications. Bilateral lower extremity edema suggests renal involvement, and a kidney biopsy would most likely show segmental sclerosis and foot process effacement, indicating focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. The other options are not associated with sickle cell disease or hypertension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sickle cell disease and poorly controlled hypertension, which puts him at risk for renal complications. The presence of periorbital swelling and lower extremity edema suggests nephrotic syndrome secondary to renal disease. Option (D) best fits the description of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which is commonly seen in patients with sickle cell disease and hypertension. Hypercellular glomeruli with neutrophils and subepithelial immune complex deposition are characteristic of post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Increased mesangial cellularity and mesangial immune complex deposition are characteristic of IgA nephropathy. Diffusely thickened capillaries and subepithelial immune complex deposition are characteristic of membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s medical history, hypertension, and smoking history suggest renal disease. The presence of facial swelling and lower extremity edema also supports this diagnosis. The most likely diagnosis is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), and the light and electron microscopy findings consistent with FSGS are segmental sclerosis and negative immunofluorescence with foot process effacement. Option A (hypercellular glomeruli with neutrophils and subepithelial immune complex deposition) is consistent with acute nephritic syndrome. Option B (increased mesangial cellularity and mesangial immune complex deposition) is consistent with mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis. Option C (diffusely thickened capillaries and subepithelial immune complex deposition) is consistent with membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of sickle cell disease and hypertension suggest that he may have hypertensive nephrosclerosis, which is characterized by segmental sclerosis on light microscopy and foot process effacement on electron microscopy. Options A, B, and C are more commonly seen in other types of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s medical history and current medications suggest that he may have hypertension-induced renal disease. The periorbital swelling and lower extremity edema also suggest proteinuria. Segmental sclerosis and foot process effacement are findings consistent with hypertensive nephrosclerosis. The other options suggest glomerulonephritis, but there is no evidence of an immune complex-mediated disease in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's medical history and presenting symptoms suggest renal involvement. Sickle cell disease and poorly controlled hypertension can cause renal damage. The presence of edema and hypertension also suggest renal involvement. Option D describes the findings consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which is commonly seen in patients with sickle cell disease and hypertension. Hypercellular glomeruli with neutrophils and subepithelial immune complex deposition are seen in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Increased mesangial cellularity and mesangial immune complex deposition are seen in IgA nephropathy. Diffusely thickened capillaries and subepithelial immune complex deposition are seen in membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of sickle cell disease and hypertension, which puts him at higher risk for chronic kidney disease. The periorbital swelling and lower extremity edema suggests nephrotic syndrome. Segmental sclerosis is a common finding in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in African Americans. Negative immunofluorescence and foot process effacement are also characteristic findings of this condition. Thus, the correct answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s medical history and current medications suggest that the most likely cause of the facial swelling and bilateral lower extremity edema is nephrotic syndrome, which is commonly associated with sickle cell disease and poorly controlled hypertension. A kidney biopsy would reveal segmental sclerosis, negative immunofluorescence, and foot process effacement, which are characteristic findings of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in African Americans. Option A describes post-infectious glomerulonephritis, Option B describes mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis, and Option C describes membranous glomerulonephritis, which are less likely to be associated with the patient’s clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sickle cell disease and poorly controlled hypertension which can lead to renal damage. The presence of periorbital swelling and bilateral lower extremity edema suggest renal involvement. Option D describes the findings of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis which is a common finding in patients with sickle cell disease and hypertension-induced renal damage. The other options describe findings in other types of glomerulonephritis which are less likely given the patient's history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has sickle cell disease and poorly controlled hypertension, which puts him at risk for renal disease. The periorbital swelling and bilateral lower extremity edema also suggest renal involvement. The findings on light and electron microscopy for this patient are most consistent with segmental sclerosis and negative immunofluorescence and foot process effacement, which are consistent with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), a common cause of renal disease in patients with sickle cell disease and hypertension. Options A, B, and C are more consistent with other types of glomerulonephritis.
